p: In living organisms, ROS and RNS are oxidant substances normally produced in cell metabolism and participating in several cell protecting mechanisms. However, unregulated or unbalanced levels between free radicals and endogenous antioxidants may often provoke abnormal cellular processes defined as oxidative stress [ 116, 117]. In this sense, oxidative stress can lead to pathological disorders defined as non-communicable chronic diseases, such as arthritis, asthma, cardiovascular dysfunction, autoimmune and neurodegenerative diseases, carcinogenesis, and diabetes [ 94, 107].
